titleStmt.title: Discrimination of Dysplastic Nevi from Common Melanocytic Nevi by Cellular and Molecular Criteria

affiliation.orgName: Center for Clinical and Translational Science

analytic.title: Discrimination of Dysplastic Nevi from Common Melanocytic Nevi by Cellular and Molecular Criteria

biblStruct.note: Received 16 June 2015; revised 17 October 2015; accepted 2 November 2015; accepted manuscript published online 1 July 2016; corrected proof

application.desc: GROBID - A machine learning software for extracting information from scholarly documents

p.s: Dysplastic nevi (DNs), also known as Clark's nevi or atypical moles, are distinguished from common melanocytic nevi by variegation in pigmentation and clinical appearance, as well as differences in tissue patterning.
However, cellular and molecular differences between DNs and common melanocytic nevi are not completely understood.
Using cDNA microarray, quantitative RT-PCR, and immunohistochemistry, we molecularly characterized DNs and analyzed the difference between DNs and common melanocytic nevi.
A total of 111 probesets (91 annotated genes, fold change > 2.0 and false discovery rate < 0.25) were differentially expressed between the two lesions.

An unexpected finding in DNs was altered differentiation and activation of epidermal keratinocytes with increased expression of hair follicle-related molecules (keratin 25, trichohyalin, ribonuclease, RNase A family, 7) and inflammation-related molecules (S100A7, S100A8) at both genomic and protein levels.
The immune microenvironment of DNs was characterized by an increase of T helper type 1 (IFNg) and T helper type 2 (IL13) cytokines as well as an upregulation of oncostatin M and CXCL1.

DUSP3, which regulates cellular senescence, was identified as one of the disease discriminative genes between DNs and common melanocytic nevi by three independent statistical approaches and its altered expression was confirmed by immunohistochemistry.

The molecular and cellular changes in which the epidermal-melanin unit undergoes follicular differentiation as well as upregulation of defined cytokines could drive complex immune, epidermal, and pigmentary alterations.

Dysplastic nevi (DNs), also known as Clark's nevi or atypical moles, are benign melanocytic tumors that are important to discriminate from common, benign nevi, and melanoma (Duffy and Grossman, 2012a;Goldstein and Tucker, 2013).

There is no established clinical definition of DNs, but some combination of the following criteria is generally adopted: (i) greater than 5 mm in size, (ii) variable pigmentation, (iii) asymmetry, (iv) indistinct or irregular borders, (v) existence of both raised and flat components, and (vi) red hue (Bergman et al., 1997;Tucker et al., 1997).
Histologically, DNs are characterized by various degrees of architectural disorder and cytological atypia, as well as infiltration of inflammatory cells.
These clinical and pathological features of DNs to some extent overlap with those of malignant melanomas.
There is active debate about whether DN is a distinct entity or just a subtype of common melanocytic nevus (CMN) (Ackerman, 1988;Elder, 2010).

The usage of "dysplastic" has also been a subject of argument, because the majority of DNs do not transform to malignant lesions and are thus clearly distinct from melanomas in situ that are truly dysplastic (Ackerman, 1988).
DNs have clinical significance because their presence is an important risk factor for melanoma.
Gandini et al. (2004) performed meta-analysis of 47 datasets to find risk factors for cutaneous melanoma.
Having even one atypical nevus is a considerable risk factor (relative risk ¼1.60; 95% confidence interval: 1.38, 1.85).
However, the risk of the lifetime transformation of a DN lesion to melanoma was estimated as 1/ 10,000 (Tsao et al., 2003).
In addition, histological evaluation of melanoma coexisting with nevus revealed that roughly half of the nevi were CMN and half were DN (Duffy and Grossman, 2012a).

It is thus unclear whether DNs are dysplastic melanocytic neoplasms with potential to be precursor lesions of melanoma, as seen in the cancer progression model of Fearon and Vogelstein (1990) for colon cancers.
The etiology of DN is not yet very well understood.
Genetic mutations that are associated with melanoma have been studied in CMN and DN.
For example, both CMN and DN harbor BRAF mutations (V600E) at approximately 60e70% of the frequency seen in melanoma (Uribe et al., 2006;Wu et al., 2007).
Mutations in other genes, such as CDKN2A, p53, and PTEN, were also found at a similar level between CMN and DN (Duffy and Grossman, 2012b).

However, several studies identified higher incidence of heterozygous or homozygous deletions in 9p21 that contains CDKN2A in DN and malignant melanoma compared with CMN (Birindelli et al., 2000;Park et al., 1998;Tran et al., 2002).
Besides genetic factors, the tumor microenvironment may also have an important role in the pathogenesis of DN, because histology has shown the involvement of many cell types in this lesion.
Scatolini et al. (2010) studied global gene expression profiles of 18 CMNs, 11 DNs, and 23 melanomas by a cDNA microarray.
There were 24 differentially expressed genes when genomic profiles of CMNs and DNs were directly compared.
They concluded that DNs are not very different from CMNs, but they noted the heterogeneity in global transcriptional changes of DNs that may reflect the various degrees of pathological atypia.
In this study, we used a molecular approach to identify differential expression of genes/proteins between DNs and CMNs and to map resulting alterations to cell types within DNs.

Our data establish that DNs and CMNs can be discriminated at a molecular level, and mapping of differentially expressed genes establishes dysplasia in the epidermal-melanocyte unit with aberrant follicular differentiation of keratinocytes.

div.head: DNs showed distinct gene expression profiles from those of CMNs

p.s: DNs have various degrees of architectural disorder and cellular atypia among cases.
A previous report that studied the range of mild-to-severe atypia was not able to find major differences in gene expression between DNs and CMNs (Scatolini et al., 2010).

Hence, DNs included in this study were specifically chosen to be compound nevi with moderate to severe architectural disorder and cytological atypia (Figure 1a,b and d,e,patient demographics in Supplementary Table S1 online).
These lesions were often characterized by epidermal elongation and bridging (Figure 1b and c).
In addition, marked increases in CD3þ T cells and CD11cþ dendritic cells were detected in DNs compared with CMNs (Figure 1fek).
Prior work from our group has demonstrated that dendritic cells in both CMNs and DNs are characterized as largely myeloid, immature, and inflammatory (Gulati et al., 2015).
By double immunofluorescent staining, DNs contained both CD3þCD8þ cytotoxic T cells and CD3þCD8-helper T cells (Supplementary Figure S1 online).
Gene expression profiles of DNs (n ¼ 7) and CMNs (n ¼ 5) were then compared with those of normal skin (NRML, n ¼ 6).
There were 745 up-and 885 downregulated probesets in CMNs compared with NRMLs (fold change > 2.0 and false discovery rate < 0.10).
A total of 376 up-and 166 downregulated probesets were found in DNs compared with NRMLs.
There were 364 commonly regulated probesets between CMNs and DNs.
A total of 178 probesets were uniquely regulated in DNs, whereas 1,266 were specific for CMNs.
Table 1A shows the top 20 upregulated probesets in DNs compared with NRMLs (complete list can be found in Supplementary Tables S2 and S3 online).
Melanocyte-related genes such as TRPM, TYR, and MLANA were consistently upregulated in both DNs and CMNs compared with NRMLs.
There were several groups of genes whose expression levels were significantly higher in DNs versus NRMLs compared with CMNs versus.
NRMLs.
These included follicular keratinocyte-related genes (KRT25, TCHH, KRT27, and KRT71) and inflammatory molecules such as S100A8 and S100A7.

These results suggest that DNs contain distinct gene expression profiles from those of CMNs, and the larger number of uniquely regulated genes in CMNs as compared with DNs could be due to the different types of CMNs included in the analysis.

div.head: DNs were characterized by increased expression of hair follicle-related genes

p.s: The purpose of this study was to provide a molecular characterization of DNs and to compare it with that of CMNs.
We thus directly compared gene expression profiles of these two lesions (Table 1B and C).
KRT25, TCHH, and KRT71 were significantly upregulated in DNs compared with CMNs (false discovery rate < 0.25).
Overall, 111 probesets (representing 91 annotated genes) were differentially expressed between DNs and CMNs (Supplementary Table S4 online).
The expression of selected genes found through microarray analysis was confirmed by RT-PCR.
To generalize our observations, an additional eight DNs and six CMNs were included for RT-PCR.
MLANA, MITF, and TYR, three melanocyte markers, were equally expressed in the two lesions (Supplementary Figure S2aec online).
KRT25 and TCHH were upregulated in DNs (TCHH approached significance; P ¼ 0.06, Supplementary Figure S2d and e).
S100A8 and S100A7 were both significantly upregulated in DNs (Supplementary Figure S2f and g).
RNASE7, a follicular keratinocyte-derived microbial peptide (Reithmayer et al., 2009), was also significantly elevated in DNs compared with CMNs (Supplementary Figure S2h).

Further RT-PCR studies of malignant melanoma samples (n ¼ 19) demonstrated the presence of melanomaspecific genes such as PRAME (Clarke et al., 2015), CCL8, MAGEA3, and MAGEA6, which were not present in DN (Supplementary Figure S2iel).
For example, PRAME and MAGEA3 were expressed >32-fold higher in melanoma samples compared with DN or CMN samples.

div.head: Epidermal activation and focal expression of hair follicle-related genes were found in DNs

p.s: To evaluate the corresponding protein expression to the genes identified through microarray and RT-PCR analysis, immunohistochemistry was carried out.
Anagen phase hair follicles from normal scalp tissues and psoriasis tissues were also stained as positive controls for several molecules.
MLANA staining showed clear dermal nests in both CMNs and DNs (Figure 2b and c).
Psoriatic epidermis contained increasing MLANA positive cells compared with normal skin as we have reported previously (Figure 2d and a) (Wang et al., 2013).
MLANApositive melanocytes were also clustered in the anagen hair bulb (Figure 2e).
KRT25 weakly stained the basal layer of the epidermis of normal skin and CMN (Figure 2f and g), but strong positivity was observed in the hair bulb region (Figure 2j).
The epidermis of DNs was strongly stained for KRT25 (Figure 2h), whereas psoriatic epidermis was only weakly positive for KRT25 (Figure 2i).
KRTAP2 weakly stained the H Mitsui et al.

Molecular Characterization of Dysplastic Nevi basal and granular layers of the epidermis of normal skin and CMN, whereas it was positive for the outer root sheath of the hair shaft and hair bulb area (Figure 2k, l, and o).
There was an apparent difference of the staining of KRTAP2 in DN epidermis and psoriatic epidermis.
It stained the basal layer and rete ridges of epidermis in DNs, whereas the granular layer had strong positivity in psoriasis (Figure 2m and n).

KRT16, which showed strong positivity for the outer root sheath of the hair shaft but no staining in the hair bulb area (Figure 2t), was essentially negative in the epidermis of normal skin and CMN (Figure 2p and q).
KRT16 stained focally the DN epidermis (Figure 2r), whereas it was strongly positive throughout the epidermis of psoriasis (Figure 2s).
S100A8/A9 was negative for normal skin and CMNs (Figure 2u and v), whereas it was focally positive in the outer root sheath of the hair follicle (Figure 2y).
Both DN epidermis and psoriatic epidermis were strongly positive for S100A8/A9 (Figure 2w and x).
These data indicate that the DNs show an aberrant activation of epidermal keratinocytes with focal follicular differentiation that is distinct from psoriatic hyperplasia.

div.head: The immune microenvironment of DNs is characterized by concomitant activation of T helper type 1 and T helper type 2 T-cell subsets with coexpression of key regulatory molecules

p.s: Given increased numbers of T cells and myeloid dendritic cells in DNs, we wanted to quantify immune-related cytokines in the microenvironment of DNs by means of RT-PCR, a more sensitive method to detect gene expression of cytokines compared with microarray techniques.
IL12B was significantly elevated in DNs compared with CMNs (Figure 3b).
Its heterodimer partners IL12A and IL23A were also slightly elevated in DNs compared with CMNs, though these did not reach the statistical significance.
IFNg, IL10, and IL13 were significantly upregulated in DNs compared with CMNs and NRMLs (Figure 3def).

In contrast, IL17A, IL17F, and IL22, key pathologic cytokines for epidermal thickness, were barely detectable in the three lesions, suggesting minimal involvement of these cytokines (Figure 3g and h).
IL24, another cytokine that drives 3j).
IL9, a cytokine recently associated with immune rejection of melanoma (Purwar et al., 2012), was not detected in any lesions except two DNs (Figure 3k).
Foxp3, a marker for regulatory T cells, was upregulated in DNs compared with CMNs (Figure 3l).

In addition, immune suppressive molecules that have been described in the melanoma microenvironment such as PDCD1, PDCD1L2, and CTLA4 were significantly upregulated in DNs compared with CMNs and NRMLs (Figure 3meo).
Overall, the microenvironment of DNs is characterized by activation of T helper type 1 and T helper type 2 T-cell subsets with coexpression of many regulatory cytokines or proteins.
The factors that activate melanocytes were elevated in DNs
Although DNs included in this study displayed epidermal hyperplasia, neither IL22 nor IL24 was increased.
Instead, we found an upregulation of oncostatin M (OSM) in DNs compared with CMNs by RT-PCR (Figure 4a).

The antibody for OSM receptor (OSMR), a cognate receptor subunit for OSM, showed membrane pattern staining on the epidermal keratinocytes of DNs, but only weak staining was observed on the epidermal keratinocytes of CMNs and normal skin (Figure 4b and c and Supplementary Figure S3a online).
Nevus cells in both lesions did not show positive staining of OSM receptor, suggesting that keratinocytes are the major target cells of OSM.
It should be noted that follicular keratinocytes clearly expressed this receptor (Supplementary Figure S3b and c).
Keratinocytes, on activation, are able to produce various factors that affect melanocyte proliferation or function (Hirobe, 2005).
The expression of selected melanocyte stimulatory factors that can be produced from keratinocytes was assessed by RT-PCR and immunohistochemistry.

Among molecules tested, we found an elevated expression of CXCL1, a chemokine that induces proliferation of melanocytes and melanoma cells (Figure 4def; Mockenhaupt et al., 2003;Richmond et al., 1985), and GM-CSF (Figure 4jel) in DNs compared with CMNs.
CXCR2, a receptor for CXCL1, was also increased in DNs (Figure 4gei).
Double immunofluorescent staining detected Ki67þ MART1þ cells more frequently in DNs compared with CMNs where only scarce copositivity was found (Figure 4m and n).

div.head: DNs can be molecularly distinguished from CMNs

p.s: To determine if we could derive a discrete molecular classification of DNs versus CMNs based on microarray data, multiple classifiers using the algorithms available at the R's suite caret were built and the top three in terms of training and cross-validation performance were selected (Supplementary Table S5 online).

The top three classifiers were able to predict all samples with 0% error (training error, Supplementary Table S5) and included ELASTIC NET (37 genes with cross-validation error rate of 8.3%, Zou and Hastie, 2005), TGDR (210 genes with cross-validation error rate of 8.0%, Ma and Huang, 2009; Tian and Sua ´rez-Farin ˜as, 2013a), and LASSO (8 genes with cross-validation error rate of 17%, Tibshirani, 1996).
Thus, the most parsimonious model was ELASTIC NET.
Eight genes were commonly identified across the three analyses including ABCB7, ABHD10, CASP4, DUSP3, LASP1, MIOS, NUDT9, and TRIM38 (Figure 5a and b).
The protein expression of DUSP3 was evaluated in DNs and CMNs (Figure 5c and d).
DUSP3 staining was increased in the epidermis of DNs compared with CMNs.
In CMNs, the staining of DUSP3 diminished as nevus nests got deeper, whereas it remained consistent in DNs.
DUSP3 expression in cultured keratinocytes and melanocytes was confirmed (Figure 5eeh).
Overall, our study demonstrated that DNs are distinctive from CMNs in many aspects and can be differentiated from CMNs at a molecular level.
A multiple step tumorigenesis model has been proposed for colorectal cancer progression (Fearon and Vogelstein, 1990).
Consistent with this model, DNs are sometimes viewed as intermediate lesions between CMNs and melanomas clinically, histologically, and genetically (Miller and Mihm, 2006).
The theory emphasizes that accumulation of gene mutations in a sequential manner is required for tumor progression from hyperplasia to dysplasia to neoplasia.
However, there remains controversy whether this model can be applied to melanocytic skin tumors.
Furthermore, despite the appreciable differences in histology between CMNs and DNs, there remains debate whether DN is a unique entity or just a subtype of CMN.

Apart from genetic mutation events restricted to melanocytes, we hypothesize that DNs are lesions developed by complex cross-talk between multiple cell types including keratinocytes, melanocytes/nevus cells, and infiltrating inflammatory cells (Supplementary Figure S4 online).
In this context, mutations in keratinocytes or other cell types might contribute to tissue dysplasia.
Our RT-PCR data indicated differences between DNs and both CMNs and malignant melanoma samples.
Therefore, DNs appear distinct from CMNs, and not simply because they are overlapping with malignant melanomas.

Previous work has demonstrated that PRAME and S100 genes are upregulated in malignant melanoma compared with nevi (both common and dysplastic) (Clarke et al., 2015), and we confirmed these findings by RT-PCR (Supplementary Figure S2).
An unexpected finding of this study was a significant upregulation of follicular keratinocyte-related genes in DNs compared with CMNs.
This was confirmed by RT-PCR and immunohistochemistry.
In interfollicular epidermis, melanocytes are thought not to actively move, proliferate, and produce melanin without external stimuli, such as ultraviolet exposure and inflammatory conditions.
In contrast, melanocyte stem cells are thought to reside in hair follicles.
They travel to the hair bulb of anagen phase hair follicles, become activated, and produce melanin for hair pigmentation without external stimuli (Nishimura, 2011).
Thus, the follicular differentiation of keratinocytes seen in DNs may create a microenvironment that facilitates proliferation and activation of melanocytes.
Our results may in part explain underlying mechanisms of clinical features of DNs.
DNs included in this study displayed epidermal acanthosis with rete elongation, but no increases in IL22 or IL24.
Instead, we found OSM to be upregulated in DNs compared with CMNs.
A subunit of its cognate receptor, OSM receptor, seemed to be induced on the epidermis of DNs.
Interestingly, OSM receptor was constitutively expressed on follicular keratinocytes, further supporting our notion of a focal follicular differentiation of the DN epidermis.
OSM potentiates keratinocytes in culture to produce various factors including S100A proteins and CXCL1, and enhances the proliferation of keratinocytes (Gazel et al., 2006).
Potentially, OSM induces the production of CXCL1 from the epidermis in DNs.
CXCL1 in turn could facilitate proliferation of nevus cells.
Indeed, the hyperproliferative nature of DNs was demonstrated by us and others (Lebe et al., 2007) via showing increased Ki67 positivity in DNs compared with CMNs.
Continued proliferation of nevus cells could explain the relatively larger sizes of DNs compared with CMNs.

Our results may also inform on the lamellar fibroplasia observed in DN, as one of the genes upregulated in DNs compared with CMNs, formyl peptide receptor 3 (Table 1B), has recently been implicated in fibrosis (Rossi et al., 2015).
IFNg was increased in DNs.
IFNg stimulates various cells to produce chemokines such as CXCL-9, -10, and -11.
These chemokines further recruit immune cells into the lesion.
Beyond its effect on immune cells, a role of IFNg in suppressing melanogenesis has been suggested (Son et al., 2014).
In humans, a single injection of IFNg into the dermis significantly reduced the expression of melanogenesis-related genes (Johnson-Huang et al., 2012;Supplementary Table S6 online).
OSM has also been shown to reduce the expression of MITF in human melanoma cells, resulting in suppression of synthesis of enzymes that are required for melanogenesis (Durda et al., 2003).
It is also noted that IFNg induced the expression of immune suppressive molecules such as PDCD1 and CTLA4 in melanoma (Spranger et al., 2013).

We would thus characterize the immune microenvironment of DNs as T helper type 1 (IFNg) and T helper type 2 deviated (IL-13) with strong coactivation of negative immune regulators (Foxp3, CTLA4, and the PDCD1-PDCD1L2 coreceptors).
Eight disease classifier genes were identified across the three independent analyses.
DUSP3, also known as Vaccinia H1-related dual-specific protein tyrosine phosphatase, is a member of MAP kinase phosphatases (Ishibashi et al., 1992).
It has been shown that DUSP3 is essential for cell cycle progression and loss of this molecule induces cellular senescence (Rahmouni et al., 2006).

Immunohistochemistry showed stronger positivity in both epidermis and nevus cells in DNs, a lesion with a more hyperproliferative phenotype, compared with CMNs, a lesion considered to be in cellular senescence.
Interestingly, in CMNs, staining of DUSP3 diminished along with the depth of the nests, in other words, maturation process.
These data suggest that DUSP3 may be involved in the cell cycle regulation in melanocytic tumors, although further study will be required to establish a role of DUSP3 in this aspect.

We acknowledge that a larger sample size is required to ascertain which if any of these candidate classifier genes can be used to molecularly distinguish DNs from CMNs, as has recently been done to distinguish melanomas from nevi in general (Clarke et al., 2015).

Applying this approach to a larger sample size could also reveal variations in expression profiles among different types of CMNs (congenital, compound, intradermal, and junctional), as well as between DNs of different levels of dysplasia.
The exact nature of nevus cells of DNs is not fully characterized yet.
Gao et al. (2012) studied gene expression profiles of established melanocytes from DNs and patient-matched normal skins.
Although the authors identified different signaling pathways between the two melanocyte groups, they were not able to detect any differentially expressed genes.

After an up to 10-day culture to establish melanocytes, they may not necessarily represent their physiological phenotype, that is, rapid proliferate state in culture versus more quiescent state in the skin.

Therefore, alternative approaches may be required to address this issue, including laser capture microdissection, a technique that allows fine dissection of skin tissues into areas of interest (Mitsui et al., 2012).

In summary, DNs are characterized by alterations in keratinocytes and local immune activation consisting of infiltrating T cells and dendritic cells with concomitant production of inflammatory cytokines and chemokines.
Epidermal keratinocytes express numerous molecular markers of follicular differentiation, and the pattern of rete elongation could represent early stages of follicular patterning.

We thus question whether a dysplastic nevus might be best characterized as a unique dysplasia of epidermal keratinocytes and melanocytes, rather than being an intermediate phenotype in neoplasia and progression to melanoma.
This hypothesis is supported by our data showing a paradoxical increased number of significantly deregulated genes in CMNs versus DNs compared with NRMLs.
Overall, we describe a set of changes that distinguishes DNs from CMNs, and the molecular discrimination of DNs and CMNs suggests some functional pathways that may underlie these distinct features.
Further study will be required to determine the relative contributions of these different pathways to DN pathogenesis.
The detailed protocols and statistical analysis are described in Supplementary Materials and Methods online.
Institutional review board and written informed consent were obtained before enrolling patients to participate in this study.
The study was performed in adherence with the Declaration of Helsinki Principals.
Excisional biopsies of CMNs, DNs, and NRMLs were performed at the Rockefeller University, the Charite University, and the Tel-Hashomer Hospital.
Five CMNs, seven DNs, and six NRMLs were subjected to cDNA microarray analysis.
An additional six CMNs and eight DNs were included for RT-PCR validation.
The 11 NRMLs included for RT-PCR validation were a different cohort of patients from the NRMLs included for the cDNA microarray study.
Total RNA was extracted from sliced frozen tissue sections using an RNeasy Kit (QIAGEN, Valencia, CA).
Target amplification and labeling was performed according to the Affymetrix protocols for two-cycle cDNA synthesis (Affymetrix, Santa Clara, CA).
Affymetrix HGU133 2.0 plus arrays were used.
The data have been deposited at the Gene Expression Omnibus repository (GSE accession number GSE53223).
The preamplification quantitative RT-PCR technique was used for measuring mRNA expression values according to the company's instruction (Applied Biosystems, Foster City, CA).
All data were normalized to RPLP0/hARP.
Primers and probes used in this study are listed in Supplementary Table S7 online.
Frozen skin sections were prepared and standard procedures were used.
Antibodies used in this study are listed in Supplementary Table S8 online.
Normal human epidermal keratinocytes and normal human epidermal melanocytes were purchased from PromoCell (Heidelberg, Germany) and Lonza (Walkersville, MD), respectively.
Both cells were maintained in the appropriate media and conditions.

For cytostaining, cells were cultured in a chamber slide (Thermo Scientific, Waltham, MA), fixed in 4% formalin (Fisher Scientific, Waltham, MA), permeabilized with 1% Triton X-100 (Sigma-Aldrich, St Louis, MO), followed by standard procedures.
Antibodies used in this study are listed in Supplementary Table S8.
Microarray data were analyzed using R/Bioconductor packages (www.r-project.org).
The Harshlight package (Sua ´rez-Farin ˜as et al., 2005) was used to scan Affymetrix chips for spatial artifacts.

Differentially expressed genes were defined using a cutoff of false discovery rate < 0.10 and fold change > 2.0 for CMNs and DNs versus normal skin and a cutoff of false discovery rate < 0.25 and fold change > 2.0 for CMNs versus DNs.

Disease discriminative analysis was performed using regularized binary classification algorithms, which combine feature (gene) selection with discriminant analysis to produce a classification rule on high-dimensional data.
Classifiers were built using a large number of learning algorithms available at the R's suite caret and in house code for TGDR (Tian and Sua ´rez-Farin ˜as, 2013b).
The top three in terms of training and cross-validation performance were selected.
Statistical analysis of all RT-PCR data was performed using Graphpad Prism ver.5 (GraphPad Software, La Jolla, CA).
A P < 0.05 was considered as statistically significant.
Figure 1.
DNs showed distinct gene expression profile compared with CMNs.
H&E staining of a representative (a) CMN and (b) DN lesion included in this study is shown.
(c) Epidermal thickness was compared between CMN and DN.
Normal skin (NRML) and psoriasis lesional skin (PSO LS) are presented as references.
An unpaired t-test was used to compare CMN and DN, and P-value is shown.
Immunohistochemistry for (d, e) MLANA, (f, g) CD3, and (i, j) CD11c for both CMN and DN is represented.
Bar ¼ 100 mm.
Positive cell count for (h) CD3 and (k) CD11c in CMN and DN was compared.
A Mann-Whitney test was used and P-value is shown.
CMN, common melanocytic nevus; DN, dysplastic nevus; H&E, hematoxylin and eosin.
Figure 2. Epidermal keratinocytes of DNs were focally activated with an increased expression of follicular keratinocyte-related proteins.

Protein expression of selected differentially expressed genes between DNs and CMNs identified by genomic analysis was examined on normal skin, CMN, DN, psoriasis lesional skin (PSO LS), and hair follicle.
(aee) MLANA, (fej) KRT25, (keo) KRTAP2, (pet) KRT16, (uey) S100A8/9.
Bar ¼ 100 mm.
CMN, common melanocytic nevus; DN, dysplastic nevus.
Figure 3. Microenvironment of DNs was characterized by an expression of mixed T-cell subset cytokines with an exception of IL-9, IL-17, and IL-22.
Cytokines and markers that indicate T-cell polarization were compared by means of RT-PCR between normal skin (NRMLs, n ¼ 11), CMNs (n ¼ 12), and DNs (n ¼ 14).
(a) IL12A, (b) IL12B, (c) IL23A, (d) IFN gamma, (e) IL10, (f) IL13, (g) IL17A, (h) IL17F, (i) IL22, (j) IL24, (k) IL9, (l) Foxp3, (m) PDCD1, (n) PDCD1L2, and (o) CTLA4.
A line between two dot plots; statistical significance between the two conditions (one-way ANOVA with Tukey's correction).
CMN, common melanocytic nevus; DN, dysplastic nevus.
Figure 4. Keratinocyte-derived factors may influence the growth of nevus cells in DNs.

Cytokines including chemokines and growth factors as well as their receptors were examined in normal skin (NRMLs), CMNs, and DNs by RT-PCR: (a) OSM, (d) CXCL1, (g) CXCR2, (j) GM-CSF, and immunohistochemistry (b, c) OSMR, (e, f) CXCL1, (h, i) CXCR2, and (k, l) GM-CSF.
A line between two dot plots in (a), (d), (g), and (j); statistical significance between the two conditions (one-way ANOVA with Tukey's correction).
Bar in immunohistochemistry ¼ 100 mm.
Double immunofluorescence staining for Ki67 (green) and MART1 (red) was performed on a representative (m) CMN and (n) DN lesion.
Scale bar ¼ 100 mm.
CMN, common melanocytic nevus; DN, dysplastic nevus; OSM, oncostatin M; OSMR, OSM receptor.
Figure 5. DNs can be molecularly distinguished from CMNs.
Disease discriminative analysis was performed using multiple informatics approaches.
(a) A Venn diagram shows overlap of the identified genes between three discriminative analyses (LASSO, ELASTIC NET, and TGDR).
CV, cross-validation error rate.
(b) The eight overlapping genes across the approaches are listed.
DUSP3 staining on (c) CMN and (d) DN tissue is shown.
DUSP3 staining on cultured (e) normal human epidermal keratinocytes (NHEK) and (g) normal human epidermal melanocytes (NHEM) is shown.
Isotype IgG2A staining on cultured (f) NHEK and (h) NHEM is shown.
Bar ¼ 100 mm.
CMN, common melanocytic nevus; DN, dysplastic nevus.
Probesets differentially regulated in dysplastic nevi and common nevi A. Upregulated probesets in dysplastic nevi and common melanocytic nevi compared with normal skin (FDR < 0.10)
